channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: 27 hospitalized, including 4 children, after car plows into Liverpool FC parade
item.description: A 53-year-old man is in police custody. He is from the Liverpool area and is believed to be the driver, police said.
item.content:encoded:
A 53-year-old man is in police custody. He is from the Liverpool area and is believed to be the driver, police said.

(Image credit: Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Romo

item.title: FBI reexamining Dobbs opinion leak, D.C. pipe bombs and White House cocaine cases
item.description: Dan Bongino, the deputy director of the FBI, says the bureau is refocusing on cases that pointed to "potential public corruption."
item.content:encoded:
Dan Bongino, the deputy director of the FBI, says the bureau is refocusing on cases that pointed to "potential public corruption."

(Image credit: Brendan Smialowski/AFP)
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Diaz

item.title: What Trump's cuts to intelligence could mean for national security
item.description:
It's a classic Washington power move — the late-on-Friday news dump.

This past Friday, at 4:30pm, start of a long holiday weekend, about half the staff of the National Security Council got emails asking them to leave by 5pm. Dozens of people abruptly dismissed.

The restructuring of the NSC as Secretary of State and National Security advisor Marco Rubio has characterized it — continues a trend in this second term for President Trump, of radical downsizing.

The Trump administration plans to cut thousands of intelligence and national security jobs across the government.

The US Government has long relied on scores of intelligence officials across the government to keep America safe. Trump wants many of them gone – what could that mean for security at home and abroad?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
It's a classic Washington power move — the late-on-Friday news dump.

This past Friday, at 4:30pm, start of a long holiday weekend, about half the staff of the National Security Council got emails asking them to leave by 5pm. Dozens of people abruptly dismissed.

The restructuring of the NSC as Secretary of State and National Security advisor Marco Rubio has characterized it — continues a trend in this second term for President Trump, of radical downsizing.

The Trump administration plans to cut thousands of intelligence and national security jobs across the government.

The US Government has long relied on scores of intelligence officials across the government to keep America safe. Trump wants many of them gone – what could that mean for security at home and abroad?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

item.title: Canada welcomes King Charles against a backdrop of tensions with Trump
item.description: The king's visit is being seen in Canada as an opportunity for the nation to bolster its sovereignty amid threats by President Trump to turn the United States' northern neighbor into the 51<sup>st</sup> state.
item.content:encoded:
The king's visit is being seen in Canada as an opportunity for the nation to bolster its sovereignty amid threats by President Trump to turn the United States' northern neighbor into the 51st state.

(Image credit: Ben Stansall)
item.dc:creator: Jackie Northam

item.title: Trump calls Putin 'absolutely crazy' following Russia's latest barrage on Ukraine
item.description: Trump's remarks were a rare rebuke of the Russian president and followed a storm of drone and missile attacks on Ukrainian cities on Sunday evening.
item.content:encoded:
Trump's remarks were a rare rebuke of the Russian president and followed a storm of drone and missile attacks on Ukrainian cities on Sunday evening.

(Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)
item.dc:creator: Jackie Northam

item.title: 5 years after anti-police protests, initiatives for officer mental health have traction
item.description: Efforts to improve officers' mental health have grown over the past five years. They were sparked in part by the death of George Floyd, which prompted a wave of anti- police protests.
item.content:encoded:
Efforts to improve officers' mental health have grown over the past five years. They were sparked in part by the death of George Floyd, which prompted a wave of anti- police protests.

(Image credit: Katja Ridderbusch)
item.dc:creator: Katja Ridderbusch

item.title: Honoring fallen military service members this Memorial Day
item.description: It's Memorial Day. To honor the fallen military service members this year, the Up First newsletter asked readers to share stories of their loved ones.
item.content:encoded:
It's Memorial Day. To honor the fallen military service members this year, the Up First newsletter asked readers to share stories of their loved ones.

(Image credit: Win McNamee/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: The CFPB wanted medical debt to be left off credit reports. That's changed under Trump
item.description: Under the Biden administration, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau finalized a rule barring medical debt from appearing on credit reports. Now, the agency is siding with the credit industry groups suing to have the rule vacated.
item.content:encoded:
Under the Biden administration, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau finalized a rule barring medical debt from appearing on credit reports. Now, the agency is siding with the credit industry groups suing to have the rule vacated.

(Image credit: Saul Loeb)
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Romo

item.title: Vets in LA hope, with Trump order, that they can finally come home
item.description: President Trump has ordered a Veterans Affairs campus in West Los Angeles to house 6,000 homeless vets by 2028, but details are elusive.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump has ordered a Veterans Affairs campus in West Los Angeles to house 6,000 homeless vets by 2028, but details are elusive.

(Image credit: Quil Lawrence)
item.dc:creator: Quil Lawrence

item.title: The European Space Agency will beam the famous 'Blue Danube' waltz into space
item.description: A performance of the masterpiece will be transmitted into space on Saturday. The waltz has been associated with space travel since its inclusion in the film 2001: A Space Odyssey.
item.content:encoded:
A performance of the masterpiece will be transmitted into space on Saturday. The waltz has been associated with space travel since its inclusion in the film 2001: A Space Odyssey.

(Image credit: ESA)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Hersher
